awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Soft Robotic Toolkit for Students and Researchers
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of entry-level, open-ended, soft robotics kits with accompanying curricular materials. The goal of the proposed technology is to enable students and researchers to test and prototype soft robots with an easy-to-use platform. The proposed open-ended kit will include portable and compact control hardware alongside materials and instructions for building soft sensors and actuators.  This information will enable high-school students, undergraduate design teams, and academic and industrial researchers to create their own soft robots, which will enable both education and research applications of soft robotics by students, researchers, and hobbyist-makers.  The proposed technology may be a gateway that can further motivate students to learn about soft robots, engineering, science, and mathematics.  

This I-Corps project is based on the development of entry-level soft robotic kits aimed at middle and high school students that will include materials, building guides, and curriculums to create soft finger-like grippers using tendon and pneumatic actuation methods.  The proposed technology platform includes a catalog of design and fabrication rules for soft robots, guidelines for simulating fluid-structure interaction with finite element modeling, demonstration and validation via hardware, documentation of research results, engineering student education, and an open-source platform for sharing the research with the broader educational and research communities. The kits consist of 3D computer aided design (CAD) models, simulation files, and fabrication instructions that may be adapted for other applications.  Combining soft robotic technology with applications involving human interaction and the use of social and people-centric applications is expected to attract a more diverse population to the study of STEM (science, technology, mathematics, and engineering) subjects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
The Soft Robotics Toolkit (SRT) is an online resource for soft roboticists and educators, historically providing access to key designs and mechanisms commonly used by this field of research. One of the offerings is the Pneumatic Controller (PC), a controller for simple soft robotic systems, helping researchers and students explore the world of pneumatic soft robots. Another specific kit, the Gripper Kit (GK), was designed for 4-12th grade students. In this experience, students fabricate their own soft grippers from silicone, learning about mold making, casting, robotic actuation, and control. These kits have been tested in classrooms and summer camps and have been developed across several iterations to conform to the needs of teachers and students alike.

Through the National I-Corps program we launched a customer discovery research phase for our kits, interviewing at least one hundred educators, parents, and teachers to better understand the need for novel STEM kits. We identified that interdisciplinary and future-focused kits could inspire students to rethink robotics and were popular with end users and potential buyers. After this program, we focused on expanding the GK as it had many, if not all, of the parameters identified throughout our interview process. Some of the highlights from this project include a collaboration with EXPLO summer camps, giving around 45 kids a hands-on experience with the revised GK. This experience ended with surveys and further redesign of the GK to fit the needs of users. We also redesigned the GK using low-cost materials for ease of manufacturing and to lower barriers to entry for future potential customers. We engaged with MassRobotics and the Boston Museum of Science in multiple outreach events, igniting enthusiasm for soft robotics (and gathering valuable insight into the needs of teachers and their students, as well as parents). We successfully executed an online SRT Design Competition in 2023 and participated in multiple conferences for robotics and education in the Boston area.

Intellectual Merit: The SRT project continues to contribute to the advancement of knowledge in the field of soft robotics. The development of the PC and educational kits like the GK encourage students to explore creative solutions in designing soft robots. Through experimentation and problem-solving, individuals gain practical skills and develop their capacity for innovation. Through the SRT project, we have facilitated collaborations with multiple institutions and summer camps. This collaborative approach enhances knowledge-sharing and the exchange of ideas within the local robotics community. Researchers, students, and educators from diverse backgrounds can come together to learn, experiment, discuss and generate new insights.

Broader Impacts: Our tools and kits serve as educational resources, both for our team as developers learning how to make better educational products, and for the end-users of students and teachers. These experiences actively educate and inspire the next generation of roboticists and engineers through hands-on learning and intuitive design. We reached thousands of students, teachers and parents during the outreach events in 2023, and many reported high levels of engagement and satisfaction with the experience. These events led to additional interviews with interested parties. The SRT kits continue to inspire young learners, particularly in K-12 settings, to engage with robotics and engineering concepts in a unique way. By empowering researchers and students with our SRT kits, the future of the robotics field will have a community of creative thinkers, more commercially viable products and a next generation of innovators with an understanding of the possibilities for robotics.


Last Modified: 01/16/2024
Modified by: Conor Walsh
